Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Sam Raskin is "Factorization Categories in the Geometric Langlands Correspondence." The host institution for the fellowship is the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Roman Bezrukavnikov.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the early 19th century, Gauss proved his celebrated quadratic reciprocity theorem, establishing a surprising connection between solutions to different equations involving different prime numbers. Throughout the subsequent century, a number of similar, increasingly complicated reciprocity laws were found. These results found eventually found their home in the theory of class fields, due to Kronecker, Weber, Hilbert and Takagi. Later, Artin, Taniyama, Shimura, Weil, and Langlands found conjectural non-abelian extensions of these earlier abelian reciprocity laws. These non-abelian reciprocity laws found their ultimate form in Langlands's conjectures, which have since proved to be a cornerstone of number theory and representation theory.

Later, Deligne and Drinfeld found avatars of class field theory and Langlands's conjectures in algebraic geometry. The theory, now called geometric Langlands, has since found connections to infinite-dimensional representation theory and mathematical physics.

My NSF proposal concerned an extension of local geometric Langlands to the setting of factorization categories, in which local points of a curve are allowed to vary and collide. Factorization has proved an essential tool in geometric Langlands. Beilison-Drinfeld introduced it to construct global invariants in the Langlands program via chiral homology. V. Lafforgue has exploited it over function fields to find Langlands parameters for automorphic representations in positive characteristic. Currently, Fargues-Scholze are working on an extension of Lafforgue's construction applicable to mixed characteristic local fields.  

My project led to a factorization extension of Arkhipov-Bezrukavnikov's fundamental duality theorem on Whittaker sheaves on the affine flag variety. The formulation involves a semi-infinite flag variety, rather than the traditional affine flag variety.

I also worked on some fundamental problems in the nascent local geometric Langlands theory. First, I attempted to formulate a spectral side of the equivalence. Here I gave a close study of the spectral side of the local geometric Langlands equivalence, the stack of de Rham local systems. I obtained partial results in this project.

Second, I developed a new theory of compact approximation for Whittaker categories; given the fundamental role of the Whittaker construction in geometric Langlands, this has proved useful in subsequent work. My work here also expressed affine W-algebra representations via Whittaker models. Using Feigin-Frenkel duality, we obtained a fundamental duality result in local geometric Langlands. Moreover, this perspective on W-algebras clarifies their representation theory.

While completing this research work, I aimed to find Broader Impacts in my mentorship work. I mentored undergraduate and graduate students. With undergraduate students, I have focused on helping them navigate and develop techniques in number theory, algebraic geometry, and representation theory. With graduate students, I have helped them work on finding research problems, develop technical training in geometric Langlands, and find strategies for solving research problems. I also participated in a summer school and co-organized a winter school directed at graduate students.
